docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON - The question-and-answer session between President Obama and House Republicans last week seemed to offer an unusually frank and refreshingly substantive debate, especially on the subject of health care.

headline.main: A Deep Divide Separated by Plenty of Common Ground

docs.abstract: Congress and presidents have failed for decades to come to an agreement on health care reform, unaware that they have long been closer than they think.
docs.snippet: Congress and presidents have failed for decades to come to an agreement on health care reform, unaware that they have long been closer than they think.

docs.lead_paragraph: The dysfunctional Congress needs shock therapy, not a talking cure from a president with large legislative majorities and powerful strings to pull.

docs.lead_paragraph: James O'Keefe III, the guerrilla videographer, advised conservative students this month that they needed to start taking more risks. ''The more you put yourself out there and you take those calculated risks,'' he told the Web site CampusReform.org, which works to foster conservative activism on college campuses, ''you're actually going to get opportunities.''
docs.abstract: Videographer James O'Keefe is arrested along with four other men on charges of trying to tamper with office telephone system of Louisiana Sen Mary Landrieu; O'Keefe says he was trying to determine whether Landrieu was avoiding constituent complaints about Senate health care bill; those arrested represent provocative conservative movement that adapts methods of leftist activists to upend what it sees as overwhelming liberal biases on college campuses and culture at large; photos (M)
docs.snippet: James O'Keefe III, the guerrilla videographer, advised conservative students this month that they needed to start taking more risks.      ''The more you put yourself out there and you take those calculated risks,'' he told  the Web site...

byline.original: By JIM RUTENBERG and CAMPBELL ROBERTSON; Reporting was contributed by Cheryl Miller, Liz Robbins and Scott Shane

docs.lead_paragraph: ANGELL--Frank. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the family of Professor Frank Angell. Professor Angell was a Renaissance man in every sense of the word. He wrote six books starting with The Treatise "Insurance: Principles and Practices" in 1959 (at about 894 pages) in the slightly briefer "Health Insurance" in 1963 (at about 600 pages). He touched so many people's lives/shaped them fundamentally. Professor Angell was a one man NYU Alumni networking service. If you needed financing, he hooked you up with a wealthy NYU Grad. If you needed credit or banking, he would set you up with an NYU Alumnus who went into banking. For over 40 years Professor Angell was NYU's most popular Professor. His class was by far the most sought after in NYU's history. He was generous with his time and wisdom. He taught about life, the real world and family values. He continued his friendship with his students long after they graduated and for that we will be forever grateful. NYU Alumni
docs.snippet: ANGELL--Frank. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the family of Professor Frank Angell. Professor Angell was a Renaissance man in every sense of the word. He wrote six books starting with The Treatise "Insurance: Principles and Practices" in 1959...

docs.lead_paragraph: International IRAQ MENDS ITS SYSTEM TO TREAT MENTAL TRAUMA
docs.snippet: International     IRAQ MENDS ITS SYSTEM TO TREAT MENTAL TRAUMA

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama has blamed many factors for the stalling of his health care overhaul, from the recent special election in Massachusetts that deprived Democrats of their supermajority in the Senate to his own failure to better explain the legislation to the American people. He has also prominently blamed lobbyists, taking them to task in his State of the Union address last week as he cited ''special interests and armies of lobbyists and partisan politics.''

headline.kicker: PRESCRIPTIONS MAKING SENSE OF THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE

docs.abstract: Pres Obama has sharply criticized lobbyists for stalling health care overhaul, but many of those lobbyists have worked to support his plan; Center for Responsive Politics estimates health care and health insurance lobbyists spent more than $648 million in 2009, dwarfing previous levels; drug companies spent over $245 million on lobbying last year, largely in support of health care overhaul; photo (M)
docs.snippet: President Obama has blamed many factors for the stalling of his health care overhaul, from the recent special election in Massachusetts that deprived Democrats of their supermajority in the Senate to his own failure to better explain the legislation...
